entry.title: Winter Storm Warning issued March 12 at 11:53AM MDT until March 14 at 6:00AM MDT by NWS Pueblo CO
entry.summary:
* WHAT...Heavy snow expected. Total snow accumulations of 5 to 14 inches. Winds gusting as high as 35 mph.
* WHERE...Western Mosquito Range Above 11000 Feet, Eastern Sawatch Mountains Above 9000 Feet.
* WHEN...From 6 PM this evening to 6 AM MDT Thursday.
* IMPACTS...Travel could be very difficult. The hazardous conditions could impact the morning or evening commute.

entry.title: High Surf Advisory issued March 13 at 2:46AM ChST until March 14 at 3:00PM ChST by NWS Tiyan GU
entry.summary:
* WHAT...For the High Surf Advisory, large breaking waves of 10 to 12 ft. For the Coastal Flood Statement, isolated minor coastal flooding.
* WHERE...North and east facing reefs.
* WHEN...For the High Surf Advisory, until 3 PM ChST Thursday. For the Coastal Flood Statement, through Thursday afternoon.
* IMPACTS...Some water on low lying roads and property. Dangerous swimming and surfing conditions and localized beach erosion.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS...Surf is expected to slowly decrease through the rest of week. First dropping below 12 feet along north facing reefs, and then along east reefs around Thursday. The risk for coastal flooding is also decreasing as the peak of the King Tide has past.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Majuro

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 8:36AM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks AK
entry.summary:
Northeast winds of 15 mph gusting to 30 mph over Steese, Elliot and Dalton Highway Summits will continue into tonight. This is causing causing blowing and drifting snow and wind chills to 35 below over summits. Snow drifts and could make travel difficult over summits.
People traveling over summits of the Steese, Elliott and Dalton Highways north of the Chatanika River should be prepared for severe winter conditions.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Dalton Highway Summits; White Mountains and High Terrain South of the Yukon River

cap:parameter.value: Windy With Blowing Snow Over Summits

entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Georgia...
Spring Creek near Iron City (CR 16) affecting Miller, Seminole and Decatur Counties.
For the Spring Creek...including Iron City (CR 16)...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Spring Creek near Iron City (CR 16).
* WHEN...Until Wednesday evening.
* IMPACTS...At 16.0 feet, Spring Creek begins to overflow low lying areas.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday the stage was 16.9 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 11:45 AM EDT Tuesday was 16.9 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 13.0 feet tomorrow evening. - Flood stage is 16.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 16.8 feet on 07/26/2013. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 11:06AM CDT by NWS Chicago IL
entry.summary: Strong southwest winds, dry vegetation, and low relative humidity will result in another period of elevated fire danger this afternoon. Any grass or brush fires that ignite will likely become difficult to control. Exercise extreme caution with any outdoor burning or open flames and with the disposal of smoking materials.

entry.title: Fire Weather Watch issued March 12 at 7:48AM MDT until March 13 at 7:00PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
...FIRE WEATHER WATCH IN EFFECT WEDNESDAY AFTERNOON THROUGH EARLY EVENING DUE TO STRONG WINDS AND LOW HUMIDITY...
.Forecast wind speeds for today have decreased, therefore only spotty critical conditions are expected and the Fire Weather Watch has been cancelled. However, on Wednesday westerly winds will increase once again. Critical fire weather conditions are possible across the East Central Plains where these strong winds, near 15 percent humidity values and above normal temperatures will exist.
* AREA AND TIMING...East Central Plains (Zone 126) Wednesday afternoon through early evening.
* 20 FOOT WINDS...West 25 to 35 mph with gusts near 50 mph.
* RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Dropping between 12 and 17 percent.
* IMPACTS...Any fires that develop will likely spread rapidly. Outdoor burning is not recommended.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:29AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary: Cold air in place over the far northern inner channels, Glacier Bay, and the northeast Gulf Coast will be over run by a front with considerable moisture on Wednesday night. Snow from this front is forecast to begin early on Wednesday and increase in intensity through the day. Peak snowfall rates are expected during the night Wednesday night, then diminish rapidly on Thursday morning. Highest snowfall accumulations are expected along the Haines and Klondike highways. There is lower confidence in snow totals for Yakutat due to the possibility of stronger southerly push behind the front raising temperatures high enough to limit accumulation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: City and Borough of Yakutat; Municipality of Skagway; Haines Borough and Klukwan

cap:parameter.value: POTENTIAL FOR HEAVY ACCUMULATING SNOW WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 5:29AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
Long range computer models are coming into agreement about a moderate to heavy rain event for the middle of the week. The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area, with the heaviest rates expected Wednesday night into Thursday. Current 24 hour precipitation totals for the panhandle from Wednesday morning through Thursday morning range from 1 to 2.5 inches, with the highest totals along the outer coast and southern panhandle. By the end of the work week, the plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend. Snowmelt at higher elevations will add to the heavy precipitation near sea level that may result in flooding along creeks, streams, and rivers. Ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage may also become an issue.
We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Glacier Bay; Eastern Chichagof Island; Cape Fairweather to Lisianski Strait; City and Borough of Sitka; Admiralty Island; City and Borough of Juneau; Petersburg Borough; Western Kupreanof and Kuiu Island; Prince of Wales Island; City and Borough of Wrangell; Ketchikan Gateway Borough; City of Hyder; Annette Island

cap:parameter.value: WARMING TEMPERATURES WITH PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN BEGINNING IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS WEEK

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 4:17AM MDT by NWS Albuquerque NM
entry.summary:
Mountain snow and lower elevation rain showers will spread across western and northern NM Wednesday, creating slick travel above 8,000 feet. Conditions deteriorate Thursday and Friday as a strong backdoor cold front surges down the eastern plains and funnels through the gaps of the central mountain chain. This will drop snow levels down to near valley floors and create damaging wind gusts up to 70 mph in east Albuquerque near the base of Tijeras Canyon. Gusty east winds combined with moderate to locally heavy snowfall rates could also create blizzard-like conditions along I-40 through Tijeras Canyon and over the Continental Divide along US-550 and I-40. Significant snowfall accumulations and patchy blowing snow will create hazardous travel conditions elsewhere in the high terrain of western and northern New Mexico Thursday and Friday, particularly over mountain passes. Slick travel may linger into the weekend and early next week, although confidence is lower given the high storm track uncertainty. Travelers should closely monitor the forecast for updates in the coming days.
Monitor NOAA weather radio, weather.gov/abq or your local media for the latest weather updates. You may also monitor road conditions online at nmroads.com, via telephone at 1-800-432-4269, or by dialing 5-1-1 in New Mexico.
entry.cap:areaDesc: Northwest Plateau; Chuska Mountains; Far Northwest Highlands; Northwest Highlands; West Central Plateau; West Central Mountains; West Central Highlands; Southwest Mountains; San Francisco River Valley; Tusas Mountains Including Chama; Jemez Mountains; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Espanola Valley; Santa Fe Metro Area; Middle Rio Grande Valley/Albuquerque Metro Area; Lower Rio Grande Valley; Sandia/Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Estancia Valley; Central Highlands; South Central Highlands; Upper Tularosa Valley; South Central Mountains; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass; Far Northeast Highlands; Northeast Highlands; Union County; Harding County; Eastern San Miguel County; Guadalupe County; Quay County; Curry County; Roosevelt County; De Baca County; Chaves County Plains; Eastern Lincoln County; Southwest Chaves County; San Agustin Plains and Adjacent Lowlands

entry.summary:
...The National Weather Service in Seattle WA has issued a Flood Warning for the following rivers in Washington...
Skokomish River At Potlatch affecting Mason County.
.The Skokomish River will continue to rise into this morning, cresting later this morning, due to heavy rainfall since yesterday across the southern Olympics.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Skokomish River at Potlatch.
* WHEN...Until late this evening.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 3:37AM CDT by NWS Green Bay WI
entry.summary:
Recent dry conditions, warming temperatures, increasing southwest to west winds and low relative humidity will result in elevated fire weather conditions across north-central, northeast and central Wisconsin this afternoon. The main concern will be in grassy areas.
Persons are urged to be careful with any activities that could potentially lead to a wildland fire. Campfires, outdoor grills, smoking materials, chain saws, and all-terrain vehicles all have the potential to throw a spark and ignite a wildfire.
Debris burning is the number one cause of wildfires in Wisconsin. Contact the Wisconsin Department of Natural Resources to check on any burning restrictions that may be in place in your area.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 12 at 2:42AM CDT by NWS La Crosse WI
entry.summary:
The combination of very low relative humidity values, warm temperatures, and dry fuels will result in elevated fire weather conditions this afternoon across southeast Minnesota and southwest into central Wisconsin. Afternoon relative humidity values fall to 15 to 25 percent with winds veering from the west to the northwest through the afternoon. West of the Mississippi River, wind speeds will be 5 to 10 mph with an occasional gust to 15 mph. East of the river, wind speeds will be 10 to 15 mph with gusts up to 20 mph.
Under these conditions, fires will start and spread easily. Please exercise caution with any activities that involve outdoor fires or create sparks, including campfires, grilling, and operating large equipment. Cigarettes should be disposed of and extinguished properly. Please heed any local burn bans.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 9:04PM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* A weak winter weather system continues to impact the region tonight. This system will bring another round of light snow to the Sierra through Tuesday morning, followed by widespread gusty winds through Tuesday afternoon.
* Additional snowfall through Tuesday will be light with a trace to two inches below 7000 feet and up to six inches along the Sierra crest. Even light snow accumulations can lead to slick roads, so plan extra time for your travels, especially the Tuesday morning commute.
* Wind gusts on Tuesday afternoon will reach 80 to 100 mph along ridges with 30 to 40 mph in Sierra valleys. Lower elevation winds will quickly diminish overnight Tuesday, while Sierra crest winds remain elevated much of this week. Expect bumpy flights and choppy lake waters.
* Drier weather is favored from midweek onward with increasing potential for a strong northeast to east wind event on Thursday into Friday.

entry.title: Flood Warning issued March 11 at 8:37PM CDT until March 13 at 1:00AM CDT by NWS Shreveport LA
entry.summary:
...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in Texas...
Attoyac Bayou Near Chireno affecting San Augustine, Nacogdoches, Shelby and Rusk Counties.
For the Attoyac Bayou...including Chireno...Minor flooding is forecast.
* WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast.
* WHERE...Attoyac Bayou near Chireno.
* WHEN...Until early Wednesday morning.
* IMPACTS...At 14.0 feet, Expect lowland flooding for the next several days of the heavily wooded floodplain. Ranchers that have cattle and equipment near the river should move them to higher ground.
* ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 7:30 PM CDT Monday the stage was 14.1 feet. - Bankfull stage is 14.0 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 7:30 PM CDT Monday was 14.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to fall below flood stage tomorrow morning and continue falling to 12.5 feet Saturday evening. - Flood stage is 14.0 feet. - Flood History...This crest compares to a previous crest of 14.5 feet on 12/19/2015. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood
entry.cap:areaDesc: Nacogdoches, TX; Rusk, TX; San Augustine, TX; Shelby, TX

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:30AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
After multiple weaker systems move through the area early in the week, long range computer models are coming into agreement about moderate to heavy rain and much warmer temperatures returning to southeast Alaska. These conditions may result in increased runoff that could cause flooding along creeks and rivers as well as ponding in areas with poor or blocked drainage. We will continue to monitor this potential hazardous situation.
The initial surge of moisture will move over the panhandle on Wednesday followed by more moisture Wednesday night and Thursday. Each will bring periods of moderate to heavy precip to the area. Over the latter part of the week, a plume of moisture directed over more southerly locations will shift northward, bringing another round of moderate to heavy precipitation rain rates.
Wednesday into Thursday, 24 hour QPF amounts have a 50 to 90% chance of more than 1 inch of moisture with a lower probability of greater than 2 inches along western slopes. Some of that moisture may start out as snow before switching to rain.
In addition to the heavy precip, another concern is a significantly warmer low level airmass that is projected to move over the panhandle. This warmer air may result in snow levels rising to more than 4000 feet across the southern panhandle and from 2000 to 3500 feet over the northern panhandle by next weekend.

cap:parameter.value: WARMING TEMPERATURES WITH PERIODS OF HEAVY RAIN BEGINNING IN THE MIDDLE OF THIS WEEK

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:14AM AKDT by NWS Juneau AK
entry.summary:
AFTER A COUPLE WEAKER SYSTEMS PASS BY EARLY IN THE WEEK, LONG RANGE COMPUTER MODELS ARE COMING INTO AGREEMENT ABOUT MODERATE TO HEAVY RAIN AND MUCH WARMER TEMPERATURES RETURNING TO SE AK. THESE CONDITIONS WOULD RESULT IN INCREASED RUNOFF THAT COULD CAUSE FLOODING ALONG CREEKS AND RIVERS AS WELL AS PONDING IN AREAS WITH POOR OR BLOCKED DRAINAGE. WE WILL CONTINUE TO MONITOR THIS POTENTIAL HAZARDOUS SITUATION.
THE INITIAL SURGE OF MOISTURE WILL MOVE INTO THE PANHANDLE ON WEDNESDAY FOLLOWED BY ANOTHER WEDNESDAY NIGHT AND THURSDAY. EACH WILL BRING PERIODS OF MODERATE TO HEAVY PRECIP TO THE AREA. THEN OVER THE LATTER PART OF THE WEEK, A PLUME OF MOISTURE DIRECTED OVER SOUTH LOOKS TO SHIFT NORTHWARD THROUGH THE PANHANDLE, BRINGING ANOTHER ROUND OF INCREASED RAIN RATES.
WEDNESDAY INTO THURSDAY, 24 HOUR QPF AMOUNTS HAVE A 50 TO 90% CHANCE OF MORE THAN 1 INCH OF MOISTURE WITH ISOLATED 20 TO 50% CHANCE OF GREATER THAN 2 INCHES ALONG WESTERN SLOPES. SOME OF THAT MOISTURE MAY START OUT AS SNOW BEFORE SWITCHING TO RAIN.
IN ADDITION TO THE HEAVY PRECIP, ANOTHER CONCERN IS A NOSE OF WARMER AIR THAT IS PROJECTED TO MOVE INTO THE PANHANDLE. THIS NOSE OF WARMER AIR COULD PUSH SNOW LEVELS TO OVER 4000 FEET ACROSS THE SOUTHERN PANHANDLE AND 2000 TO 3500 FEET OVER THE NORTHERN PANHANDLE BY NEXT WEEKEND.
SURFACE TEMPERATURES WILL RESPOND AS WELL. NEXT SATURDAY, COMPUTER MODELS ARE GIVING THE ENTIRE PANHANDLE A 70 TO 100% CHANCE OF SEEING MAX TEMPS GREATER THAN 40 DEGREES. FOR MAX TEMPS GREATER THAN 45 DEGREES, AREAS ALONG AND SOUTH OF FREDERICK SOUND HAVE A GREATER THAN 60% CHANCE WHILE AREAS TO THE NORTH OF FREDERICK SOUND HAVE A 10 TO 40% CHANCE.

entry.title: Special Weather Statement issued March 11 at 11:47AM PDT by NWS Reno NV
entry.summary:
* Mostly dry conditions prevail through this afternoon ahead of another weak system moving into the region tonight. This system will bring another round of light snow to the Sierra this evening into Tuesday morning, followed by widespread gusty winds through Tuesday afternoon.
* Additional snowfall through Tuesday will be light with a trace to two inches below 7000 feet and up to six inches along the Sierra crest. Even light snow accumulations can lead to slick roads, so plan extra time for your travels, especially the Tuesday morning commute.
* Wind gusts on Tuesday afternoon will reach 80 to 100 mph along ridges with 30 to 40 mph in Sierra valleys. Lower elevation winds will quickly diminish overnight Tuesday, while Sierra crest winds remain elevated much of this week. Expect bumpy flights and choppy lake waters.
* Drier weather is favored from midweek onward with increasing potential for a strong northeast to east wind event on Thursday into Friday.
